title: How to Wash a Silk Pillowcase

steps.headline: Read the label on the pillowcase to check how it should be washed.
steps.description: The label is normally on an inside corner of the pillowcase. It will indicate whether hand washing, machine washing, or dry cleaning is recommended. If the pillowcase doesn't have a care tag attached, get it dry cleaned to be on the safe side.

steps.headline: Spot treat any stains on the pillowcase.
steps.description: Use a stain remover that indicates that it is safe for silk on the label. Apply the stain remover to the stains only. Choose an inconspicuous area such as an inside corner of the pillowcase to test that the stain remover doesn't discolor the fabric.

steps.headline: Mix lukewarm water with 1/2 tsp (2.5 mL) of laundry detergent in a bucket.
steps.description: Fill up a bucket halfway with warm water. Add in your preferred laundry detergent. Check the label first to ensure that the laundry detergent is safe for silk. Try to find a gentle or natural based laundry soap to protect your silk pillowcase.

steps.headline: Soak the pillowcase in the bucket for 5 minutes.
steps.description: Place the pillowcase into the bucket of lukewarm water and laundry soap. Set a timer so that you know when 5 minutes is up. Don't soak the silk pillowcase for longer than 5 minutes as this can cause shrinkage. You can swirl the silk gently while it is soaking if you prefer, but never scrub or wring it as this can damage the delicate fibers.

steps.headline: Drain the water and laundry soap mixture from the bucket.
steps.description: Once 5 minutes is up, drain the water and soap from the bucket into the sink. Hold the silk pillowcase while you drain the liquid so that it stays in the bucket.

steps.headline: Refill the bucket with cool water, white vinegar, and fabric softener.
steps.description: Add ¼ cup (59 mL) of white vinegar, several drops of a fabric softener, and 0.9 US gal (3.4 L) cool water into the bucket. Let the silk pillowcase soak in this mixture for 1 minute. Check that the fabric softener is safe for silk before you use it. The white vinegar will remove any excess soap and alkalinity, and the fabric softener will make the silk feel soft.

steps.headline: Drain the bucket of liquid and rinse the pillowcase out.
steps.description: Pour the water, white vinegar, and fabric softener mixture from the bucket. Use fresh, cool water to thoroughly rinse the pillowcase. Make sure that you rinse both the inside and outside of the pillowcase by turning it inside out as you rinse it.

steps.headline: Lay the pillowcase flat on a dry towel.
steps.description: Remove the rinsed pillowcase from the bucket. Place it directly onto the towel. Make sure that none of the edges are folded.

steps.headline: Roll up the towel from the edge to start drying the pillowcase.
steps.description: Start from the edge of the towel, and roll up both the towel and the silk into a cylinder shape. Press on the rolled towel gently so that it absorbs the excess water from the pillowcase. Don't squeeze the towel tightly or vigorously, as this could damage the silk. Just pat it carefully.

steps.headline: Lay the pillowcase flat on a fresh towel to let it dry.
steps.description: Unroll the pillowcase from the damp towel. Lay out a fresh towel, and place the pillowcase onto it. Leave the pillowcase there until it has fully dried. Never hang up silk items on a clothesline to dry, and always dry them out of direct sunlight. The pillowcase will take 1-2 days to dry, depending on the climate.

steps.headline: Check the label on the pillowcase before using the washing machine.
steps.description: The label will indicate if the pillowcase will be safe in the washing machine. Some silk items can only be dry cleaned, and the label will indicate this. Get the pillowcase dry cleaned if it doesn't have a care label.

steps.headline: Pick a delicate and cold temperature cycle on the washing machine.
steps.description: The maximum water temperature that is safe for silk in a washing machine is 30 °C (86 °F). Choose the most gentle and delicate cycle that is available to avoid damaging the pillowcase. Silk can shrink if it is washed in temperatures that are greater than 30 °C (86 °F).

steps.headline: Put the pillowcase into a laundry bag and then into the washing machine.
steps.description: Make sure that the laundry bag is large enough to fit the pillowcase. Put the laundry bag into the machine. The laundry bag prevents the silk from being damaged by the washing machine drum.

steps.headline: Add a mild laundry detergent and start the cycle.
steps.description: Follow the instructions on the label of the laundry detergent, and make sure that you don't use too much. Press the start button to begin the washing cycle. A gentle, non-alkaline detergent is usually best for silk items. If the pillowcase is colored, make sure that the detergent doesn't contain any bleaching chemicals. The label on the detergent will indicate if it does.

steps.headline: Leave the pillowcase resting flat on a clean towel to dry.
steps.description: Remove the pillowcase from the laundry bag when the washing cycle is finished. Lay it flat on a clean towel, and leave it there until for 1-2 days or until it's dry. Never tumble dry silk as this will damage it. Keep the pillowcase drying on the towel out of direct sunlight.
